intro: Coreopsis hawaiensis, commonly known as the Hawaiian coreopsis, is a flowering plant native to the island of Hawaiʻi. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble daisies. The plant typically grows in coastal areas and has adapted to the unique climate and soil conditions of the Hawaiian archipelago. Its bright yellow flowers bloom in the spring and summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
